Dear all,

I'm forwarding an email I've just received since it is highly relevant to
this list. Apologies if you received it already.

Best,
Vassilis


---------- Forwarded message ----------
From: Julian Miller <julian.miller@...>
Date: Wed, Sep 18, 2013 at 1:48 PM
Subject: [ml-worldwide] First CFP: Special Issue of Natural Computing:
Neuroevolution
To: ml-worldwide@...


Neuroevolution of Indirect Representations of Neural Networks

This special issue of Natural Computing seeks high quality original work
relating to the evolution of indirect representations of
artificial neural networks (ANNS). Papers submitted can be original
research papers or survey papers.

In nature biological neural networks are created through an exceptionally
indirect process. A single set of evolved genes in a single fertilized
ovuum produces a network with an enormous number of cells and connections.
In other words, the genotype to phenotype mapping is extremely indirect and
complex. In addition, the process is ongoing during the lifetime of the
individual.

Indirect genotype representations of ANNS do not use a one-to-one mapping
of weights and connections to genes
in the genotype. Typically, such mappings may be generative or
developmental in nature, highly redundant or compressed. Usually, when such
mappings are evolved small genetic changes can induce large scale changes
in the networks (phenotypes). For instance a single gene change may cause
multiple weights to change, neurons being disconnected and others
connected, or large scale topological changes in the network.  The aim of
such mappings is to make ANNs more evolvable and often to scale up to large
networks capable of solving complex and large scale problems. Indirect
mappings may be used in many kinds of neural networks: non-spiking,
spiking, recurrent, etc.

Relevant topics for the special issue include:

Generative or developmental neural networks;
Highly compressed genotype-phenotype mappings of neural networks;
Highly redundant mappings in which many genes may be ignored in building
the neural network;
Evolutionary representations of neural networks that include greater
biological plausibility;
Evolutionary representations which include an encoding of neural learning
rules;


To submit a paper follow the instructions at:

https://www.editorialmanager.com/naco/

Please make clear that submissions are intended for the special issue
entitled:

"Neuroevolution of Indirect Representations of Neural Networks"

Submission system opens: June 1, 2014.

Closing date for submissions: September 1st, 2014.

Informal enquiries can be emailed to  the guest editor:

Dr. Julian Miller
Department of Electronics
University of York
julian.miller@...

*********************************************************************

 Reader, Department of Electronics (Athena-Swan bronze award)

http://www.mitpressjournals.org/loi/evco
